title: Open Structures
segmentation: I'd like to talk about open structures.net, which is approach that actually quite some of you have also been collaborating on.
And.
Deals with the question.
It deals with the question how to integrate time with in design.
Now what?
Do we mean with that?
It deals with the question how to design A built environment that can easily learn, evolve and adapt.

We used to because if if we have objects that behave as dynamic puzzles rather than static objects, then they can adapt to ever changing ever changing contexts, and that's something I think we deal with very frequently today.

Our context is changing more quick than ever before, so how can we design objects that can deal with that and therefore will enable us to use them for longer time and develop a different relationship?
With them
Not soon enough.
This question brought us to looking into modular systems because they are exactly the kind of things that look into this question now.
Every one of us or whoever played with Lego knows that illegal car.
It's not a car is just a bunch of parts that come together at a certain point in time for Makar together to then evolve into a crane or whatever you want it to.
Or you could even take it apart again an exchange parts with your friend or whatever.
So we took this ancient principle and this came from a very first.

We had very ecological or unsustainable motives, because this kind of this way of constructing and designing things like within the design you have already integrated the aspect of time, and this will allow us to use things longer.
So it took this ancient pincher principle that worked, and we thought, OK, how could we update this?
How could we adapted to more modern context?
So we combine it with the Wikipedia model, the network model.
Which is a different way of how we construct things.
How we create things.
So basically where this is how Lego was constructed, you have one producer, one company, that designs a complete system.
All the parts from the first part to the last part protects them and then sells them to the end user.
So you have one designing for all.
What the open Structures Project proposes is a kind of modular system.
We're actually all design A smaller part of a larger system.
So just as in Wikipedia, everybody writes one article, then contribute to one big encyclopedia in Europe and Structures Project is everybody can contribute a part or an object an to a larger system.
Where is Wikipedia used?
Uses HTML as it's kind of common language that allows all the contributors to read articles of others, but also to edit them and upload their own articles.
Construction Project proposes a geometrical bridge that is built up out of squares of 4 by 4 centimeter and that also defines.
A certain assembly points in its diagonals.
This script is used as a common design tool.
For all the contributors.
So the ideas.
If everybody designs from the same grid.
Then what you get is.
A lot of very different parts objects that are all very that all have the signature of the maker in it.
Some parts are low tech or others are high tech, some use ceramics, some.
Metal.
But
So on.
What you see here is a number of parts that have all been designed by different people, but all from their own background from their own skill from their own way of looking at things.
But actually all connected or.
Based on the same grid, so meaning that they are all compatible.
With one another and they can all be combined and.
Objects, So what you get is a kind of modular system, but that no longer has uniform identity.
There is no longer if you look at Lego, all the parts they fit to one another, but they're all out of plastic and they're all out of five colors in this modular system.
The ambition is to create the model, your system where no longer see the modularity in it, or it's kind of hidden.
It's more in the DNA of the parts rather than in the outlook.
So this parts have then been combined into objects.
I'm showing you a number of objects that have been created over the years, So what we do is we.

We ask people to work with it and.
